overview: From 2025-09-23 to 2025-09-24, ethereum-optimism/optimism had 12 new PRs (9 merged), 5 new issues, and 27 active contributors.

topIssues.title: enable flashblocks on sunnyside sequencers.
topIssues.author: yashvardhan-kukreja
topIssues.body: After the success of enablement of flashblocks on all the sequencers of mainnet, enable them on sunnyside, with basic healthiness criteria.

topIssues.title: alerting setup of flashblocks
topIssues.author: yashvardhan-kukreja
topIssues.body: Have an alerting setup in mainnet to ensure paging the on-call whenever respective issues occur with flashblocks production

topIssues.title: op-batcher: revisit usability of throttling config
topIssues.author: geoknee
topIssues.body:
* deprecate `throttle-threshold-multiplier`
* check if there is a minimum (or "always") throttle size for transactions
* should step function be aligned with the start or the end of the range of the linear/quadratic controller? or in the middle?
* the default values need another look, especially since they relate to pending block da bytes, not total unsafe da bytes (which will be much higher).

recommended settings 
* minimum threshold should allow for one probably 2 channels to fill up with no throttling
* max threshold should be 10 to 50x to get decent smoothness.

topIssues.title: op-sync-tester: Support EL Sync Testing
topIssues.author: pcw109550
topIssues.body:
We plan to remove the remove req-resp p2p sync path and rely increasingly on EL Sync for keeping the chain state up to date. To ensure this transition is safe, we need to verify that EL Sync is functioning correctly under real-world conditions.

Our sync tester does not validate EL Sync against real chain data yet. We extend the sync tester to include EL Sync checks, confirming that it reliably syncs blocks and state without depending on p2p req-resp.

topPRs.title: op-node,op-program,kona: embed L1ChainConfig in configuration
topPRs.author: geoknee
topPRs.body:
Since [Ecotone](https://specs.optimism.io/protocol/ecotone/l1-attributes.html), the L1BlockInfo deposit transaction couples the L2 state transition with the blob base fee of the l1 origin. The blob base fee is not part of the block, but rather computed from `block.excessBlobGas` with an [off-chain formula which varies according to which fork is active on L1.](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth/blob/51614a3dc4af4a2b503ba178e0799013e6774613/consensus/misc/eip4844/eip4844.go#L180-L197)

For the L2 state to accurately reflect the blob base fee of the l1 origin, it is necessary to provide the L2 consensus client information about the fork schedule of the L1 which it derives from.

This PR does that in a relatively lightweight way:
* for chains with a recognized l1 chain ID (such as all chains in the superchain registry), lookup the l1 chain config (either for Mainnet or Sepolia) using op-geth as a library. This information needs to be kept updated as new L1 forks (including BPO or blob parameter only forks) are scheduled in upstream geth and brought in through upstream merges. When this happens, we need to update the absolute prestate for the proofs system
* for custom chains (think devnets, test environments, chains which are not in the superchain registry) it is required to pass the l1 chain config via a new CLI flag. This can be directly JSON encoded or embedded in a `genesis.json` file.
* Does something similar for the op-program, which does not allow information to be passed at runtime but instead via filesystem embedding
* Also includes changes in this direction for kona

I avoided embedding the l1 chain config inside the `rollup.Config`, as that would require changing all of the data in the superchain registry.

This is a backwards compatible change which also makes the derivation pipeline compatible with post-Fusaka L1s.

The diff is quite large, mostly because there is a lot of boilerplate to change both in production and test code.

Closes #17493

topPRs.title: feat(ai-contracts-test): add prompt renderer component
topPRs.author: aliersh
topPRs.body:
This PR extends the AI Contracts Test Maintenance System with a **prompt renderer** that transforms the test ranking output into AI-ready prompts.

## What's New

### Prompt Renderer System
- Loads canonical prompt template from `prompt/prompt.md`
- Fills placeholders with the highest-priority test and contract paths
- Generates descriptive filenames like `{ContractName}_prompt.md`
- Consumes ranking.json from the test ranker

### Command Interface
- **`just render`** - Generate AI prompt for top-ranked test
- **`just prompt`** - Combined workflow (rank + render in one command)

## Sample Output

The prompt renderer generates files like `prompt-renderer/output/Storage_prompt.md` containing a pre-filled test and contract paths from the highest-priority ranking entry

## Documentation Updates

- Enhanced runbook with multi-step workflow instructions

topPRs.title: feat(ops): add AI Contract Test Maintenance System v0.1.0
topPRs.author: aliersh
topPRs.body:
# Add AI Contract Test Maintenance System v0.1.0

## Overview

This PR introduces the **AI Contract Test Maintenance System**, an automated toolchain designed to continuously reduce technical debt in contract tests within the `contracts-bedrock` monorepo. The system integrates with an AI coding agent to generate pull requests that improve test quality and coverage.

## What's in this PR (v0.1.0)

### Test Ranking System
- **Test selection** based on staleness metrics between test files and their corresponding source contracts
- **Two-branch scoring algorithm** that prioritizes tests whose contracts have diverged ahead, then falls back to test age
- **Git-based analysis** using commit timestamps to calculate staleness and priority scores.

## Sample Output

The system generates a ranked JSON file with entries like:

```json
{
  "generated_at": "2025-09-22T...",
  "entries": [
    {
      "test_path": "test/L1/ProtocolVersions.t.sol",
      "contract_path": "src/L1/ProtocolVersions.sol", 
      "staleness_days": -98.21,
      "score": 135.84
    }
  ]
}
```

Higher scores indicate higher priority for maintenance attention.

## Documentation

- **Operational Runbook** (`docs/runbook.md`) - System overview, usage, and troubleshooting

```
go test -timeout 300s -run ^TestQueue_Send_MaxPendingMetrics$ github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/op-service/txmgr -race -count=100 
```

. The above command passes on this PR.
